rsbNotes.title: Ps 58
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 58 Psalms of lament often contain sections that are curses directed against the evil and unjust. The objects of the psalmist’s scorn seem to be human rulers (v. 1 note), especially unjust judges. Early Christian tradition associated this psalm with the high priest and the Sanhedrin as they condemned Jesus (Matt. 26:57–68).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 58:1
rsbNotes.text: 58:1 you gods. The word “gods” could be used for the corrupt judges of this verse, according to the example in Ps. 82:1 (see text note).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 58:3
rsbNotes.text: 58:3 from the womb. David recognized this of himself in Ps. 51:5. All are born with a nature that rebels against God—this is the meaning of the doctrine of original sin. David means that the wickedness of the evil judges in particular extends back to the beginning of their lives.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 58:4–5
rsbNotes.text: 58:4, 5 venom of a serpent. The psalmist likens the wicked rulers to snakes. The story of the Fall (Gen. 3), initiated by the serpent, sharpens the image. The rulers’ words are as distinctive as the venom of the serpent, and they turn a deaf ear to logical arguments and even divine judgments that may be addressed to them.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 58:7
rsbNotes.text: 58:7 when he aims his arrows . . . blunted. Bring to nothing their evil schemes that seek violence against the innocent.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 58:10
rsbNotes.text: 58:10 The righteous will rejoice. Eternity will show that God’s judgment of the wicked is just. This judgment will cause rejoicing since the alternative would be unthinkable: heaven populated with God’s enemies (Rev. 16:5, 6; 19:1–3; 21:27).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 58:11
rsbNotes.text: 58:11 there is a reward. When the wicked prosper or the righteous suffer, faith is shaken. The covenant promises of Deut. 28 provide for curses on the wicked and blessings for the righteous. The last judgment will set things right again.
